6.5. NULL ValuesÂ¶

Any data type in ITTIA DB IoT can hold a special value called null, represented by the literal null. When a value is null, it indicates that the value is unknown, has not been set, or does not exist.

Columns in a table can be restricted to not contain any null values. When a row is inserted, any columns that are not set default to null.

While the SQL literal null has no inherent type, its type is usually inferred from the context of the SQL query. If the type cannot be inferred, for example when null appears in a select list, but not part of any expression, the field will have type DB_COLTYPE_UNDEFINED.

Comparison operators handle null as a special case. The result of any comparison is false whenever either value is null, and even if both values are null, because the actual answer is uncertain. To determine whether a value x is null, use the expression x IS NULL or x IS NOT NULL.

Null values are also a special case for unique indexes. If the value of an index column is null for a given row, then that row is exempt from the unique constraint.

Tip

In C and C++, NULL is a pointer type equal to 0. In SQL, 0 and null are distinct values.
